node.title: Bette Midler Is Still in the Thrall of 19th-Century Novelists
node.description: “I love Dickens and Twain above all.”
node.content: ["\u201cI love Dickens and Twain above all,\u201d says the actor and singer Bette Midler, whose latest children\u2019s book is \u201cThe Tale of the Mandarin Duck.\u201d", "What books are on your night stand now? ", "A better question is \u201cWhat\u2019s NOT on your night stand?\u201d There are things I\u2019ve been hoarding, things I don\u2019t have the courage to tackle just yet, gifts, books I buy on impulse, and P. G. Wodehouse, a perennial. One year, my family gave me the entire Penguin Classics library and some of it is rough sledding, like \u201cGargantua and Pantagruel.\u201d Politics, race, acting, history, religion, arts, the environment, detective stories, whatever the new fiction is, plus poor old Auden and Walt Whitman, who have been patiently standing by for years.", "What\u2019s the last great book you read? ", "I recently reread \u201cI Know Why the Caged Bird Sings.\u201d Hands down, one of the greatest I\u2019ve ever read. Yesterday I finished \u201cThe Parade\u2019s Gone By,\u201d by Kevin Brownlow, and it finally fell apart; it\u2019s about the silent movie era. I bought it in the \u201970s, and finally got around to reading it. Unforgettable.", "Describe your ideal reading experience (when, where, what, how).", "Hanging over the side of the bed with the book on the floor and a box of Ritz crackers nearby.", "What\u2019s your favorite book no one else has heard of? ", "\u201cSouthern California: An Island on the Land,\u201d by Carey McWilliams. A history of how Los Angeles was marketed to the unsuspecting in the Midwest, and the various scandals and horrors the local scalawags visited upon them when they arrived, as well as crimes against minorities and the land. Published in 1946.", "What book should everybody read before the age of 21? ", "W. E. B. Du Bois\u2019s \u201cThe Souls of Black Folk,\u201d \u201cPersonal Finance for Dummies\u201d and Jane Jacobs\u2019s \u201cThe Death and Life of Great American Cities.\u201d", "Which writers \u2014 novelists, playwrights, critics, journalists, poets \u2014 working today do you admire most? ", "I\u2019m embarrassed to say that I am still in the thrall of the 19th and early 20th centuries. I love Dickens and Twain above all, but there are a lot of writers working today that I admire; Michael Lewis, Jonathan Franzen, Michael Chabon, Michael Lewis, Ta-Nehisi Coates, Hilary Spurling, Matt Taibbi, bell hooks, Michael Lewis, Naomi Wolf, Eleanor Catton, Bryan Stevenson, Michiko Kakutani. Did I mention Michael Lewis? And she\u2019s not working today, but the extraordinary Nora Ephron meant the world to me.", "Who are your favorite actor-writers? Your favorite Hollywood memoir?", "I devour oral histories on movies and music: Peter Bogdanovich\u2019s \u201cWho the Devil Made It\u201d; \u201cPeople Will Talk,\u201d by John Kobal; \u201cShe Always Knew How,\u201d Charlotte Chandler\u2019s oral history of Mae West. Frank Capra, Preston Sturges, Ben Hecht, Gloria Swanson. Marlene Dietrich, by her daughter, Maria Riva. Joan Crawford\u2019s book on entertaining is hilarious. Tina Fey\u2019s book is killer. Tiffany Haddish\u2019s book, a must-read, and I loved Amy Poehler\u2019s. Candy Bergen, Sally Fields, Eve Babitz and, of course, Joan Didion have all written brilliantly about their Hollywood lives. I loved Jean Stein\u2019s last book, \u201cWest of Eden.\u201d R. J. Wagner\u2019s memoir on Hollywood, surprisingly very moving. I cried. Anita Loos\u2019s \u201cA Girl Like I\u201d is just wonderful. I wish I had known her.", " Of all the characters you\u2019ve played across different media, which role felt to you the richest \u2014 the most novelistic?", "I have played several characters who began their lives as characters in actual novels, but I guess I\u2019d have to go with C. C. Bloom, in \u201cBeaches.\u201d I know it\u2019s sentimental, and yet the span of years, the highs and lows, this relationship, the brilliant performances of Mayim Bialik and Barbara Hershey \u2014 you can\u2019t deny it certainly struck a chord.", "What character from literature would you most like to play?", "Any woman of a certain age in anything by Shakespeare, Dickens, Congreve, Dryden or Sheridan.", "What\u2019s the last book you read that made you laugh? ", "\u201cI Know Why the Caged Bird Sings.\u201d The scene in church, where a woman gets the spirit and rushes the pastor, is one of the funniest things I have ever read.", "What\u2019s the last book that made you cry? ", "\u201cI Know Why the Caged Bird Sings.\u201d", "What subject do you wish more authors would write about? ", "Race and Reconstruction. The villainy of the impeached Andrew Johnson should be common knowledge, but it is not. Our children should be made aware that we are still living with the consequences of Reconstruction. I\u2019m 75, and it was news to me.", "Which genres do you especially enjoy reading? And which do you avoid? ", "I speed read memoirs, diaries and biographies. James Beard\u2019s memoir, \u201cDelights and Prejudices,\u201d Alex Haley\u2019s \u201cMalcolm X\u201d made a huge impression on me, Andre Agassi\u2019s memoir was fantastic. \u201cChronicles,\u201d by the greatest actor of them all, Bob Dylan, is stunning, Keith Richards\u2019s \u201cLife\u201d? I went out the next day and bought a guitar. \u201cM Train,\u201d by Patti Smith, Levon Helm\u2019s \u201cThis Wheel\u2019s on Fire\u201d is great, both Aretha books by David Ritz, Roseanne Cash\u2019s book \u201cBodies of Water,\u201d Mike Stoller and Jerry Leiber\u2019s autobiography, \u201cHound Dog.\u201d The Duc de Saint Simon, three volumes at the court of Louis XIV, is superb. I recently received a copy of the unedited diaries of Chips Channon, YIKES. Still, my favorite is Quincy Troupe\u2019s book with Miles Davis, \u201cMiles: The Autobiography.\u201d And I\u2019m going on record to say I LOVED Mariah Carey\u2019s autobiography, \u201cThe Meaning of Mariah.\u201d She sent it to me with a box of Kleenex. I never, ever read horror.", "What book might people be surprised to find on your shelves? ", "\u201cThe Orvis Fly-Fishing Guide.\u201d And the Bible.", "What\u2019s the best book you\u2019ve ever received as a gift? ", "A first edition of \u201cAlice\u2019s Adventures in Wonderland.\u201d", "What kind of reader were you as a child? Which childhood books and authors stick with you most? ", "My mother taught me to read when I was 4, and I became a compulsive reader. My parents left us kids in the Honolulu public library every Saturday from 9 a.m. until 4 p.m., while they did their shopping. I wandered all over. I read Grimm\u2019s, Hans Christian Andersen, the Betsy-Tacy and Tib books, \u201cFreddy the Pig,\u201d \u201cThe Borrowers,\u201d \u201cThe Boxcar Children,\u201d \u201cThe Secret Garden\u201d (very important), a lot of boys\u2019 adventure and magazines. Especially Life! It showed me the world. When I was 12, I read \u201cThe Last of the Just\u201d and I never got over it.", "You\u2019re organizing a literary dinner party. Which three writers, dead or alive, do you invite? ", "Charles Dickens, Fran Lebowitz and Vladimir Nabokov."]
